message.text: @G[c3 stills_108.png]@L @H Message @L The Senate has sent extra funding to compensate for military buildup costs. @H Reward @L 1500 denarii acquired. @G[more_funds.png] @L@L @H Historical Background @L Roman military commanders were called legates, who were the people in charge of a single legion. These commanders held "imperium", or it could be said that they directly represented the power and being of the whole Roman state. Diplomats and consuls also held imperium, which to some extent explains the often-rude behavior of Roman diplomats sent to foreign courts and tribes. Bowing down to a barbarian king would be dishonoring imperium as if the whole of Roman civilization was bowing down. @L@L There is much to talk about regarding Roman military systems and tactics. I will cover at least some of these aspects in future missions in bits where they're practical and topical. @L@L For now, a basic explanation would be that much like the culture, early Roman military systems were heavily based upon the Greek phalanx tactics and formations along with skirmishers. @L@L During the times of the Kingdom and early Republic, Roman troops were citizens who had to buy and upkeep their own kit. As such, poor citizens would only be able to act as skirmishers using slings/javelins or light infantry. @L@L Slings were common in Greek and Roman skirmishing roles due to their availability and the fact that many agrarian workers would use slings to drive off birds eating grain while farming or to protect a herd of sheep. This made for a natural pool of poorer recruits who knew how to use a sling effectively. @L@L Slings would often be loaded with conical "bullets" made from lead or other metals, not just stones. Greek slingers would inscribe curses and mock enemies on the projectiles themselves. A hit from a sling at optimal range could cause significant concussion and damage even to troops wearing armor. Modern testing revealed slings would be capable of inflicting wounds similar to those caused by a small caliber firearm today. @L@L Bows on the other hand were only rarely used, and due to the nature of the weapon, required years of training as well as higher upkeep and production costs of the weapon itself. Certain regions like the island of Crete, did have a strong archery tradition but it is an exception, rather than a rule. @L@L Main armaments for heavy infantry included bronze or iron helmets, greaves, spears and an armor; swords only became popular later in Roman history. Heavy infantry would be called hoplites or Romanized "hoplitai", stemming from the Greek "hoplon" which is a word for equipment or "to equip". @L@L Poorer soldiers would often only have a slab of bronze strapped to the chest to protect their center instead of a full thorax armor. Greeks were very fond of lino-thorax armor which, much like medieval gambeson armor, is made up of multiple layers of compressed cloth. This was highly effective for its cost and common in its use historically, in one form or another, from Mesoamerican civilizations to China where it was made of paper and silk. @L@L Lino-thorax was however more than just layered cloth. It had less bulk since fewer layers were used and then resin or natural glue was applied. This offered great protection against cutting attacks especially. @L@L As for tactics, phalanx formations fought in organized square or rectangle shapes of massed heavy infantry armed with spears and shields. Intimidation and organization often played a part in demoralizing enemies before a battle; but the main strength of the phalanx was the pushing power, as it was almost impossible to break through the side where the phalanx was facing. @L@L Against disorganized foes, the only threat would be flanking since phalanx were very slow to turn which was its biggest weakness, or going over rough terrain which broke up the ranks. This was countered by massing more phalanx units to cover each other's flanks. If possible, cavalry and skirmishers would be used for harassment and flanking. @L@L If two phalanxes met each other on the battlefield, the unit with longer spears, better overall armor and shield quality, and discipline were favored. If the units were evenly matched, they would often clash with their shields and push until the other unit broke apart. @L@L The typical Roman legion at this time would be comprised of 3000 hoplites, 1200 skirmishers, and 300 cavalry for a total of 4500 men. You can notice that even this early the Romans preferred and fielded very infantry-centered armies. @L@L A final note about the use of bronze and iron in weapons and armor making. In European history, the Iron Age is dated to have begun around 1100 BC, thus even the earliest Romans could have had access to iron. We might think that iron is vastly superior in every way, but for ancient peoples, circumstances varied. Local deposits might be lacking or if present, smelting technology might be too primitive to effectively process it. Additionally, high-tin content bronze would often have strength comparable to iron. @L@L The downside of bronze is the need for copper as well as tin ores, which were not as abundant in every region where these civilizations were established. @L@L
